data.title: Back to school fairs held f
data.meta_description: Bread of Life Assembly Of God Church's Third Annual Community Day features backpack giveaways, fun activities
data.text:
Deadlines:

Monday-Friday 8:30am-4:00pm, Call 610-915-2226

(Proofs will be provided for accuracy only, they will not be styled/formatted like the finished product)

Obituaries submitted on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays are accepted from 8:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. by email only Obit@delcotimes.com

(No proofs will be furnished. Pricing will not be available until the next business day after 10:00am by calling Dianne at 610-915-2226)

Obituaries received after Deadline will not be published in the following edition of the paper.

Sending Procedure:

Email is the preferable method for receiving Obituaries (and the only method on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays), they can be sent to Obit@delcotimes.com (Feel free to call and confirm that we’ve received the email)

Formatting:

Obituaries will continue to visually look the same as they currently do, but you will no longer be restricted in what you can say (ex. As much Family can be listed as you’d like; Wording like “Went to rest with the Lord” is now permissible)

Other:

There is a cost for each obituary. Pricing and payments are only available Monday through Friday, 8:30 am to 4:00 pm. All weekend and holiday submissions will be provided a cost the next business day.

Exceptions:

All New accounts, Out of State Funeral Homes and Private Parties will require prepayment upon approval of the obituary. Weekend and Holiday staff are not authorized to set up a new account or process payments

Deadline for the above is before 4:00 PM Mon – Fri. only (Holiday schedules may vary).

Prepayment required submissions will be handled on the very first business day following the weekend and/or holiday schedule. A complete name, address and best contact phone number are required upon submittal of your obituary request to set up your account. A proof will then be emailed for review but placed on hold until payment is received.

UPPER DARBY — Bread of Life Assembly Of God Church’s third annual Community Day drew hundreds of local residents Saturday to Sellers Recreation Area at State Road and Penarth Avenue.

Church volunteers handed out 800 free backpacks filled with school supplies to children ages 3 to 14 years old in preparation for the start of the school year. Attendees enjoyed free food, games, face painting, bounce houses, water ice and music, all made possible by the generosity of the members of Bread of Life AG Church of Upper Darby.

Upper Darby’s police and fire departments set up information tables to provide young people with information about possible careers as first responders and careers in law enforcement, and had a fire engine on site for public viewing.

Bread Of Life Assembly of God Church is at 110 S. State Road, Upper Darby. For more information, go to https://bol.church or call 610-440-1251.

Delaware County Health Department hosts first back-to-school fair

The Delaware County Health Department will hold its first Back-to-School Fair from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. on Saturday, Aug. 10 at the Delaware County Wellness Center, 125 Chester Ave., Yeadon.

From backpacks and haircuts to health screenings and immunizations, residents are encouraged to stop by the Wellness Center at Yeadon to get ready for the upcoming school year.

Back to School Fair activities will include Tdap and MCV4 Vaccines for incoming seventh and 12th grade students. Pre-registration is required for immunizations by calling 484-276-2100.

Backpacks and school supplies will be distributed to students while supplies last to ensure they have the tools needed for academic success. The fair will also include vision and dental screenings, with quick assessments to identify any potential health issues that might affect a student’s learning.

Fun activities, like face painting, music and giveaways, will be available at the fair, as well as information and resources to support families in various aspects of health and education.

“Ensuring students are prepared and healthy as they start the school year is so important,” said department Director Melissa Lyon. “Our goal is to support our children’s health, well-being, and potential to achieve success and live a healthy life.”

The event is supported by numerous community partners, including Eagle Eye Mobile, Acme, Delaware County libraries, Keystone First, Children First, The Line Up, Kids Smiles, The Foundation for Delaware County, the Franklin Mint and Wawa.

For more information about the fair or to register for immunizations contact the Delaware County Wellness Line at 484-276-2100 or DelcoWellness@co.delaware.pa.us.

Upper Darby holds job fair

Upper Darby School District will hold a job fair for support and paraprofessionals on Monday, Aug. 12 from 1 to 4 p.m. at the Upper Darby School District Administration Building, 8201 Lansdowne Ave., Upper Darby.

Those attending can get more information as well as apply in person for open positions that include teacher assistants, substitute teachers, bus drivers, personal care assistants, crossing guards, safety officers and maintenance and facilities.

American Legion 777 invites community to annual corn boil

American Legion Post 777 will host its annual corn boil on Saturday, Aug. 17 from 1 to 5 p.m. at the post, 137 Walter St., Crum Lynne.

Adult admission is $25, and children under 12 are free. The event will feature plenty of fresh corn, hamburgers, hot dogs, water, beer and much more. Everyone is welcome. For more information, call 610-833-2891.

County’s Department of Military and Veterans Affairs to host free film screening Thursday

There will be a screening of “The Journey Home” on Thursday, Aug. 8, from 7 to 9 p.m. at Nolan’s Pour House, a veteran-owned coffee shop at 1 W. Third St., Media.

The movie is presented by the Delaware County Department of Military and Veterans Affairs.

Veterans and active-duty members of the military are invited to view the documentary and also connect with fellow service members and access valuable resources from the behavioral health community.

The documentary features numerous Vietnam veterans who share their experiences of returning home and their current lives. The film presents a complete story of what it has been like for the veterans, as they deal with a range of emotions relating to their experiences post-Vietnam.

With interviews from Academy Award Winner Jon Voight, Medal of Honor Recipient Sammy Davis, and dozens of others, the film presents a complete story of what it has been like for these returning veterans, as they deal with a range of emotions relating to their experiences post- Vietnam.

The film screening is one of county department’s ongoing efforts to raise awareness of veteran suicide and the mental health issues veterans face, and to highlight the vast resources available to Veterans and their family members who may feel isolated, overwhelmed, and in need of support.

“This powerful movie provides an honest and relatable portrayal of the struggles that many Veterans face,” said Col. Arthur Jenkins Jr., Delaware County’s director of Military and Veterans Affairs. “It sheds light on the harsh realities of veteran suicide and the importance of seeking help. We look forward to seeing both new and familiar faces on Thursday.”

Veterans, active military, or those who are concerned can call the confidential 24/7 Veterans Crisis Line by dialing 988 and then pressing 1. This line is available for all veterans and active-duty military, even if they’re not enrolled in VA benefits or health care. Support doesn’t end with the conversation. Veterans Crisis Line responders will connect callers with the resources they need.

Purple Heart Day observed with service and reception

Washington Memorial Chapel’s Veterans Commission will host a special National Purple Heart Day service and reception at 6:30 p.m. Wednesday, Aug. 7 at the Washington Memorial Chapel, 2000 Valley Forge Road, King of Prussia.

During the service, Vietnam War veteran and founder of Mount America Foundation George Turak will regale guests with stories about his time in the Vietnam War, as well as his experience forming the foundation, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that serves veterans, active duty and National Guard/Reserve service members, first responders and their families, as well as honors the families of those who paid the ultimate price.

A reception will follow the service.

Purple Heart Day, observed annually on Aug. 7, honors the brave men and women who were either wounded on the battlefield or lost their lives while serving in the military.

The day is set aside for Americans to remember and honor those who valiantly represented their country and were decorated with a Purple Heart in the name of the president. It is also a time to highlight the rich history and significance of the Purple Heart. This year marks the 10th anniversary of Purple Heart Day.

The event is free, but registration is required at http://evite.me/HWRCYtvUPj.

The commission exists to honor all those who have served our country, to show God’s love through service, to provide spiritual support to active members as well as fellow veterans and their families, and to help build stronger Christian relationships among veterans and surrounding communities. To learn more, or to schedule a tour visit, go to www.wmchapel.org/veterans.

Delaware County’s Summer Festival winds up this week

Delaware County’s Parks and Recreation Department’s Rose Tree Summer Festival in Rose Tree Park, Upper Providence, is in its final week.

The free outdoor concerts, which began on June 12 will wrap up the 2024 season with its final concert on Sunday, Aug. 11.

The entertainment changes nightly and fans experience a wide variety of genres throughout the months, including rock, pop, blues, Broadway, R&B, reggae, big band, Brazilian jazz and more.

The final evening concerts will feature Makin’ Music on Wednesday, Aug. 7. The award-winning band of teacher-performers plays an infectious mix of folk/pop music for parents to enjoy with their children.

Glenolden native singer/songwriter/pianist Barry Harris and Band will entertain on Thursday, Aug. 8. Harris will play originals and classics by Billy Joel, Bruce Springsteen, Bon Jovi and more.

Local music legend Ben Singleton will bring his party band to Rose Tree on Friday, Aug. 9 and entertain the crowd with rock, pop, R&B, Motown and Top 40 music.

Three Fourteen, a five-piece high-energy band will bring their original sound on stage, mashing up reggae, soul and psychedelia into heavy jams, on Saturday, Aug. 10.

Closing out the season will be Del’s Groove on Sunday, Aug. 11, playing popular party music for dancing and a good time.

All shows will begin at 7:30 p.m. and attendees are advised to bring chairs or blankets.

Leashed and friendly dogs may accompany guests in the outermost seating areas on the hilltops. Parking is free.

There are no rain dates, so if a show can go on safely, it will.

For more information on the concerts, visit http://delcopa.gov. To check for a cancellation message, call 610-891-4455.

Public hearings over water rate hikes to be held today in Delco

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission will hold a public hearings today in Delaware County to gather input on proposed water and sewer rate hikes.

Under the proposals, the average monthly bill for a residential water customer would increase by 19.9% ($16.10).

For residential wastewater customers, the average monthly bill would increase 18.4% ($14.92).

The Pennsylvania Office of Consumer Advocate filed with the PUC a formal complaint against these proposed rate increases.

The hearings will be held at 1 and 6 p.m. at Delaware County Community College in Room #1403 of the STEM Building, 901 S. Media Line Road, Media.

Other public hearing meetings will be held over the next week in Chester and Montgomery counties.

Interested residents are encouraged to visit the PUC’s website at puc.pa.gov for information on how the hearing will be conducted.

In addition, telephonic public input hearings have been scheduled at 1 and 6 p.m. Wednesday, Aug. 14.

To testify at one of the telephonic public input hearings, interested residents must pre-register by 4 p.m. on Tuesday, Aug. 13 by emailing PUC Legal Assistant Christina Biggica, at cbiggica@pa.gov or calling 717-787-1191 and providing first and last name, and the phone number that will be used to call into the hearing, and additional contact information.

Readers can send community news and photos to Peg DeGrassa at pdegrassa@21st-centurymedia.com.

Originally Published: August 7, 2024 at 7:01 a.m.
